steps.title: Planarity Game
steps.html:
Planarity

This is a planar graph, but the ${n} vertices have been scrambled up. Rearrange the vertices so that none of the edges overlap.

steps.title: Travelling Salesperson Map
steps.html: Try rearranging the cities on this map, and watch how the shortest path between them changes. You can remove cities by tapping them, and you can add cities by clicking anywhere on the map (up to 8):

steps.title: Three Body Problem
steps.html: What happens when three plants orbit around each other in space?

steps.title: Julia Sets
steps.html:
In this diagram, we highlight all points x0 on the complex plane, for which the recursive sequence xn=xnâ12+c is bounded (it doesn't diverge).

xn=xnâ12+${complex(c)}
x0=${complex(x0)}
x1=${complex(x1)}
x2=${complex(x2)}
x3=${complex(x3)}
â¦Bounded!Diverges!

steps.title: The Mandelbrot Set
steps.html: For Julia sets, we chose a fixed value for c, and then changed the position of x0 to colour the plane. Now letâs fix the value of x0=0, and instead change the value of c:

steps.title: Mandelbrot Zoom
steps.html:
Like all fractals, we can âzoom intoâ the Mandelbrot set forever, finding new patterns at every scale. Here you can zoom into a part of the Mandelbrot set called the Seahorse valley:

Scale: ${pow(scale)}

steps.title: The Chaos Game
steps.html:
The chaos game is a way to generate fractals using a simple rule. You start with a point, repeatedly pick a random vertex of a polygon, and then mark the midpoint of the line from your original point to that vertex. Then you continue from that new point. What shapes can you make?

Triangle
Square
Pentagon

steps.title: Apollonian Gasket
steps.html: Can you place all smaller circles inside the big one?
